title: How to Polish Larimar

steps.headline: Clean larimar with a polishing cloth immediately after wearing it.
steps.description: If you don’t have a polishing cloth available, use another type of soft, lint-free cloth. Rub the entire gemstone down as soon as you are able to. Doing it right away removes oil and before it has a chance to set in. You don’t need to use any cleaners for it. Jewelers use a polishing cloth to remove tarnish. It contains a polishing compound, so it’s more effective than any other cloth you may use. You can get polishing cloths, along with other polishing tools, online and at many jewelry counters.

steps.headline: Mix water and soap to give larimar a deeper cleaning.
steps.description: When your jewelry needs a little extra polishing, set aside a small bowl. Fill it with about ⁄2 cup (120 mL) of warm water. Then, add about 2 or 3 drops of a mild dish soap. Stir the water until it’s nice and soapy. Your regular dish soap will be fine as long as it isn’t too harsh. Avoid any products designed to cut through grease. Fragrance-free soaps made for sensitive skin or cleaning baby bottles are always good options. Most types of jewelry can be cleaned with soap and water as well. Take advantage of the soapy water to wipe clean silver and gold settings, for instance, but don’t use it on wood.

steps.headline: Scrub larimar with a soft-bristled toothbrush and soapy water once a week.
steps.description: Dip the brush into the soapy water. Lightly scrub the larimar from the top-down, clearing off any debris along the way. When you reach the base of the stone, scrub around the edges and inside the setting. Use a soft-bristled brush only. If you don’t have a good, clean brush to spare, try using a microfiber cloth instead. If you want to make absolutely sure you don’t end up scratching the larimar, purchase a baby toothbrush. Set it aside in a clean place for whenever you need to polish your jewelry.

steps.headline: Soak the larimar in the soapy water if you are unable to get it clean.
steps.description: For stubborn debris you can’t get rid of any other way, submerge the entire stone in soapy water. Leave it there for about 5 minutes. Afterward, scrub it with a soft-bristled brush or cloth again. Stains will be much easier to remove. Metal jewelry can be cleaned this way, but don’t soak anything that isn’t waterproof, such as wood. Larimar has a tendency to turn a slightly darker shade of blue in water. If you’re happy with the shade of your larimar, then continue to scrub it instead of soaking it.

steps.headline: Rinse larimar in clean water before drying it off.
steps.description: Wash off the remaining soap and debris under cold, running water. If you don’t want to soak the stone again, wipe it clean with a clean cloth dampened with a little bit of water. Once it’s done, the stone should glimmer like it did on the day you bought it. Make sure your larimar is dry so the soap and water don’t continue to soak into it. Any minerals or chemicals left could cause discolorations over time. After rinsing, you could apply a colorless oil, wax, or paraffin to fill in any scratches on the larimar. It usually isn’t needed and is mostly done by people refining gemstones.

steps.headline: Put larimar jewelry on after applying soap or oils.
steps.description: Reduce the larimer’s exposure to any kind of oily or acidic products you use on your body. This includes hand soap, hair spray, lotions, creams, and makeup. The minerals in these products can cause serious tarnishing. If you get anything on larimar, wash it off right away with warm, soapy water. When you’re done wearing larimar jewelry, take it off first. Think, “last on, first off” to minimize its contact with anything that could tarnish it. Remember to also set aside your larimar when using any sort of household chemicals, like cleaning products.

steps.headline: Take larimar jewelry off before going swimming.
steps.description: Keep your beautiful gemstones from getting doused in water. Pools and hot tubs are very damaging to jewelry because of the high chlorine content in the water. However, saltwater also tarnishes jewelry. For safety, always store larimar in a safe spot away from water. If your larimar happens to get wet, wash it off right away with soap and water. Larimar is generally safe in tap water, such as in the sink or shower. The water can cause the stone to darken a little, but it doesn’t damage metal jewelry.

steps.headline: Remove larimar before doing any sort of physical activity.
steps.description: Larimar is pretty scratch-resistant, but you still run the risk of damaging it by bumping it against solid surfaces. Take it off while exercising, for instance. Leave it behind while cleaning or similar activities. Be careful with your jewelry even when you aren’t doing anything intense. You could still knock it into a wall or table, for instance.

steps.headline: Move larimar out of direct heat and sunlight when possible.
steps.description: Take the larimar off when you’re sitting at the beach, for example. At home, keep it away from windows. Doing this will help the gemstone retain its sheen for much longer than usual. It also prevents any other parts, such as metal settings, from warping and discoloring. The sun isn’t bad in small doses, but too much of it causes larimar to fade. Whenever you’re going to be leaving larimar exposed for a long period of time, consider taking it off and folding it up in a soft cloth. Summer is the most damaging time for jewelry. On top of the heat and sunlight, you have to deal with sweat, suntan lotion, and various other things that could stain larimar. Be extra cautious and leave your jewelry at home when you don’t need it.

steps.headline: Store larimar in a lined jewelry box when you’re not using it.
steps.description: If you don’t have a fabric-lined jewelry box, wrap it up in a soft cloth. Try keeping it away from other gems and jewelry. Anything else you store with it could scratch it, ruining the finish. Harder gemstones, including diamonds, rubies, and sapphires, are some of the main culprits for unexpected scratches on larimar. Keep away metal items with sharp edges. Even if you wrap the larimar up, it could still come into contact with keys, utensils, and other potential sources of damage.

Jewelers use a polishing cloth to remove tarnish. It contains a polishing compound, so it’s more effective than any other cloth you may use. You can get polishing cloths, along with other polishing tools, online and at many jewelry counters. Mix water and soap to give larimar a deeper cleaning. This includes hand soap, hair spray, lotions, creams, and makeup. The minerals in these products can cause serious tarnishing. If you get anything on larimar, wash it off right away with warm, soapy water. When you’re done wearing larimar jewelry, take it off first. Think, “last on, first off” to minimize its contact with anything that could tarnish it. Remember to also set aside your larimar when using any sort of household chemicals, like cleaning products. For safety, always store larimar in a safe spot away from water. If your larimar happens to get wet, wash it off right away with soap and water. Larimar is generally safe in tap water, such as in the sink or shower. The water can cause the stone to darken a little, but it doesn’t damage metal jewelry. It also prevents any other parts, such as metal settings, from warping and discoloring. The sun isn’t bad in small doses, but too much of it causes larimar to fade. Whenever you’re going to be leaving larimar exposed for a long period of time, consider taking it off and folding it up in a soft cloth. Summer is the most damaging time for jewelry. On top of the heat and sunlight, you have to deal with sweat, suntan lotion, and various other things that could stain larimar. Be extra cautious and leave your jewelry at home when you don’t need it. Store larimar in a lined jewelry box when you’re not using it. If you don’t have a fabric-lined jewelry box, wrap it up in a soft cloth. Try keeping it away from other gems and jewelry. Anything else you store with it could scratch it, ruining the finish. Harder gemstones, including diamonds, rubies, and sapphires, are some of the main culprits for unexpected scratches on larimar. Keep away metal items with sharp edges. Even if you wrap the larimar up, it could still come into contact with keys, utensils, and other potential sources of damage.
